Evaluation_Questions: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken
What is your overall assessment of this course
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor
The primary instructor's provided students with helpful and timely feedback
The instructor established a positive learning environment
The instructor raised questions or problems that encouraged me to think critically
Comments_Questions: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course
Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved
Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
How would you summarize this course for a fellow student?  Would you recommend it to another student?  Why or why not
Comments_List: Around an hour
final project took about 20hrs over course of semester, otherwise less than 1 hr per week
2-3 hours most weeks. Longer when projects were due.
1-2 hours
1-10 (more when assignments were due)

This was originally supposed to be offered as a full credit course, so expectations with workload were a little unclear. Better clarity with the syllabus and an outline of how long assignments should be expected take would have been helpful (or perhaps just sticking with three assignments in total, where students are provided the freedom to pick and choose, i.e. recording a podcast OR a pitch OR profiling another student).

That said I really enjoyed profiling another student! Thought that was a great assignment and a great way to get to know one of my other classmates. I also enjoyed improv, although I know not everyone did.

Structuring student "final" projects probably would have functioned better over the course of the semester instead of backloading into the final day of class (or, at the very least, giving students more notice of what the last day of class might look like -- it was tough to have a 3 hour class during YSPH's reading week).

Strengths -- I think it's a laid back class, where you get to read some really interest material. The guest speakers were interesting and it was amazing to meet famous and established authors. 

Weaknesses- I don't think I learned a lot in this class. I think our generation knows how to use social media already so much, but it would have been helpful to get more writing assignments or know how to analyze a news article and think more critically about it. We should have had the opportunity to write and get feedback on us covering the news a bit. There was also a lot of student participation and time for them to talk, so there was little lecturing from James Hamblin.
Enjoyed, but clearly the first time it was offered. Assignments and lecture goals could be more clear. Once these are ironed out I think it will be an excellent course.

Strengths: 
+ Non-judgmental, yet engaging environment
+ Learned many practical/tactical tips needed for a career in public health/public health communication
+ Jim provided honest feedback on assignments and was always open to providing mentorship on any projects

Weaknesses
+ Feedback on assignments came many weeks after the due date

So interesting (including the course readings)! 
Every health professions student should take this course.  I loved being able to think more critically about how to address public health issues through the lens of social media and popular journalism.  I appreciated the way the professor incorporated headlines from the day into his lectures. It encouraged me to be more informed with the news--something every student could take more time to do.  

Students would be better served if this class were offered as *full credit.* I would have liked to have more discussion time each week.
I really enjoyed the course and I feel that it is an important subject to be offered in the public health curriculum.
I really enjoyed the guests we had. I thought that was a very engaging component.

Strengths: Learning from someone who does health journalism, we had very creative projects
Weaknesses: The final project was a bit unclear. I was also hoping to come out with writing samples that I could submit for job applications.
I think this course should be a full credit instead of a half credit. This change will allow us to spend more time on topics we were unable to explore thoroughly.

It was an interesting course to think about current topics and health-related issues in the media, and was a relevant and timely course for thinking about how to most effectively disseminate public health (and other) research and data to the public/different audiences. The timing of the course (Monday 6-7:20pm) was a bit un-ideal, but other than that the course was really interesting and engaging and I enjoyed the different projects throughout the semester. It would have been nice to have smaller tasks to break up the big social media projects (e.g. have your project social media account name/title due, have your first few posts drafted, etc). Overall an interesting course!
Make it a full credit course! It was awesome.

In theory, this is great class and one that this program could really benefit from given that the students need to understand how to translate the information we know in public health to the public in a way that can be easily received - through the media. However, I think this class comes with the assumption that you need to already know all of the social media platforms really well and rather are just practicing different forms of presenting to the media. I think, instead, it needs to start from scratch and establish the pros and cons of the various platforms and present how to go about using each platform effectively. To do all of this, it would be best to make this a full semester class so that the professor can go into detail rather than brushing over everything and not allowing students to fully engage.

I think this was a great addition to the course offerings at YSPH. Health communications is an up and coming field, and it is extremely important that YSPH grows the communications aspect of our program.

More discussion. Also, more concrete scope of assignments. Could have one critical question for students to respond to when reading each week's readings as a means to help aid in the depth of discussion. Would prefer  going in deeper on certain topics, versus breadth. 

Loved the speakers that were brought in.  I do think that there is value in having this type of course  offered at YSPH and I imagine some of the kinks will get worked out as this continues to be taught.

 This course and the student experience would benefit if a final project proposal was due and there was a two week time span where all students were required to meet with the instructor. 

I also think that the course could be more inclusive in terms of welcoming spectrum of capacity in social media. For example, his expectations for final project could be more experimental than sustainable.

Strength: an interesting survey of topics in health narratives that added valuable insight to my degree. 

Weakness: the class is better suited to be a full credit and did not go as in depth as I would have liked
I think there's a lot to learn from him - but wish it was more him speaking and teaching than students giving their input.

Engaging lecturer, needs clearer expectations of what he wants from assignments.  Will benefit from using our work as examples in the future. I really appreciated his flexibility and willing to meet students where they were at. Very open door communication policy. Although I think he may have overestimated how ~online~ we are.

Instructor was really engaging. Thank you for not boring us with following the format of more traditional classes. 
I appreciated the way the professor pushed us out of our comfort zones at the beginning of class by starting with improv exercises. This made me laugh and helped me to feel more at ease to participate in class.
I feel that Dr. Hamblin really made an effort to encourage the class to engage and participate. I particularly enjoyed how relevant he made the course to current events and issues in public health.
Jim is a very responsive and caring professor!

Strengths: Very creative and encouraging. I enjoyed dissecting news topics and talking about current events. He challenges us to think critically about the news we consume and also the style things are written in. 
Weaknesses: Wish the final project had been a little more clear. Feedback wasn't always the most timely.

He provides meaningful feedback, which is great for improving your work over the course of the semester. He is also very open to feedback from the students, which allows for him to improve the course as well. I enjoyed some of the guest speakers, although I would have loved to see more diversity.

Great! It was interesting to hear his perspectives and views on this topic and to hear his first-hand experiences (from him and his contacts in the media), and to learn more about health media and narratives. I enjoyed the improv during class and feel that if the course had potentially been at an earlier time in the day and/or in a smaller room that felt more seminar-style than the course would have had a stronger interactive component that Jim was going for. Overall great teaching and course!

Keeping in mind that James was a first time instructor, I think he did the best he could! I think he might work to being more receptive to students in what their comments are and how they are reacting to the class and understand what they want out of the class. He has a wealth of experience but it was no so easy to learn from that or get advice on how to pursue the path he is on. I think he has great ideas and if he had more time in class to go through them, he could be more effective.
10 out of 10 would recommend.

It was clear that this was his first time both teaching, and teaching this course. That said, James was a decent teacher. Strengths: understanding our demands and not asking us to put in too much work outside of the classroom. Weaknesses: Could improve on discussion facilitation skills.  Also, having clearer expectations of assignments. Lastly, pacing of each class.
Knowledgeable and enthusiastic instructor who could use a bit more experience in structuring an educational schedule and plan.

This is a clever and somewhat innovative/non-traditional course as far as YSPH goes. You'll create assignments that can fuel work for future projects outside of YSPH, especially if you're moving into the health communications world. It was the professor's first year teaching it this year so structure was a little rocky, but I think with kinks sorted out this will be a great class moving forward.
I think James is keen on improving the course, but I'm not sure I would recommend it unless there was a lot of content and formatting change.
Take it. YSPH needs more health media courses -- no idea why this is only half a credit and Bazell's is a full credit. This was lightyears better and more relevant to current communications.

Yes, I think everyone at YSPH should take a course in public health communication. While the class could use a bit more structure and should be longer than 80 minutes per week, overall I did leave with important tips about how to be a better public health communicator. The workload was very manageable, and th assignments were actually fun to work on and could easily be converted into a real publication, pitch, or project. Great class for a 2nd year elective if you want to learn key skills for your next job but not have to do a lot of work.
Fun, engaging, and relevant. The kind of class one hopes to be inspired by in choosing a school like Yale.
I would recommend this course to another student. I would tell them that it is best to approach it with an open mind and a willingness to participate.

This is a course about the different media sources for health journalism, primarily online. It is not a journalism course. it would be the most beneficial for someone who knows at least the basics of journalism. However, it is not hard to follow if you don't.

A course about news consumption, social media, and health communications 

Yes, I would, if there was a little bit more structure.

I think this class is extremely important, especially as social media is the way in which many people are receiving their health information. I would strongly encourage this class for individuals interested in public health communication.

It was an interesting course to think about current topics and health-related issues in the media, and was a relevant and timely course for thinking about how to most effectively disseminate public health (and other) research and data to the public/different audiences. The projects allow you to dive into your specific health interests, and are a great way to set yourself up "in the media" moving forward in your career. I'd recommend this class as a great way to think critically about how you are and will portray your work in the media.
Yes.

I would summarize it as a course that is meant for students to understand how to build a social media platform for public health related-engagement. I think with some changes, I would recommend it to other students.
Great survey of health narratives ideas for a layperson without media experience.
